'''Posthegemony''' or '''post-hegemony''' is a period or a situation in which [[hegemony]] is no longer said to function as the organizing principle of a national or post-national [[social order]], or of the relationships between and amongst [[nation state]]s within the global order.{{sfnp|Williams|2002|p=327|ps=: "Posthegemony ... is no longer a name for the hegemony of transnational capital, but the name of those 'places in which hegemony ceases to make sense' (Jean Franco)."}} The concept has different meanings within the fields of [[political theory]], [[cultural studies]], and [[international relations]]. ==In cultural studies== In the field of [[cultural studies]], posthegemony has been developed as a concept by a number of critics whose work engages with and critiques the use of [[cultural hegemony]] theory within the writings of [[Ernesto Laclau]] and within [[subaltern studies]].For example, see {{harvp|Yúdice|1995}}, {{harvp|Moreiras|2001}}, {{harvp|Williams|2002}}, and {{harvp|Beasley-Murray|2010}}. George Yúdice, in 1995, was one of the first commentators to summarize the background to the emergence of this concept:
Flexible accumulation, consumer culture, and the "new world information order" are produced or distributed (made to flow) globally, to occupy the space of the nation, but are no longer "motivated" by any essential connections to a state, as embodied, for example, in a "national-popular" formation. Their motivations are both infra- and [[Supranational union|supranational]]. '''We might say that, from the purview of the national proscenium, a posthegemonic situation holds.''' That is, the "compromise solution" that culture provided for Gramsci is not now one that pertains to the national level but to the local and transnational. Instead, the "culture-ideology of consumerism" serves to naturalize global capitalism everywhere [emphasis added].{{sfnp|Yúdice|1995|p=4}}
The concept of posthegemony is related to the rise of the "[[multitude]]" as a social force which, unlike the "people", cannot be captured by [[hegemony]], together with the roles of [[affect (philosophy)|affect]] and [[habitus (sociology)|habitus]] in mechanisms of social control and agency.These ideas are discussed extensively in {{harvp|Hardt|Negri|2000}}, {{harvp|Hardt|Negri|2004}}, and {{harvp|Beasley-Murray|2010}}. Posthegemony and its related terms are influenced by [[Gilles Deleuze]] and [[Félix Guattari]], [[Pierre Bourdieu]] and [[Michael Hardt]] and [[Antonio Negri]]’s accounts of the supra- and infra-national forces that are said to have rendered obsolete the national-popular forms of coercion and consent through which, for [[Antonio Gramsci]], hegemony structured and constituted society. The features of posthegemony as a concept correspond closely to those of [[postmodernity]]. Thus, posthegemony theory argues that ideology is no longer a political driving force in mechanisms of social control and that the modernist theory of hegemony, which depends on ideology, therefore no longer accurately reflects the [[social order]].{{sfnp|Beasley-Murray|2003|p=119}} Some commentators also argue that history is not, as [[Karl Marx]] described it, a [[class struggle]], but rather a "struggle to produce class".{{sfnp|Beasley-Murray|2003|p=120}} The concept of posthegemony also resonates with the work of post-[[Michel Foucault|Foucauldian]] theorists such as [[Giorgio Agamben]]. Nicholas Thoburn, drawing on Agamben's discussion on the "state of exception", writes that "it is, perhaps, with the recasting of the relationship between law and politico-military and economic crises and interventions that is instituted in the state of exception that the time of hegemony is most revealed to have passed."{{sfnp|Thoburn|2007|p=89}} == In international relations == In [[international relations]], ''posthegemony'' refers to the decline of the US [[Unilateralism|unilateral]] hegemony. This has likely been the result of the difficulties that have arisen out of the unilateral style [[foreign policy]]. These difficulties predominantly include disdain from; those directly affected by the, sometimes forceful, hegemonic actions of the US, those who spectated the actions, and even Americans themselves who view the actions of their government as immoral. For example, after the [[Vietnam War]], in 1978, 72 per cent of Americans thought the war was not a mistake but fundamentally wrong and immoral.{{sfnp|Hagopian|2009|p=13}} This exemplifies the hegemonic decline: how could the US maintain the legitimacy of their interventions if their own citizens find them wrong and immoral?{{tone inline|date=June 2018}} The dominant power(s) of the world is/are fluid, the initial period of US unilateralism can be loosely pinpointed to their interventions during the world wars.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}} Following this period of rising US dominance on the world stage, {{quote|there have been no shortage of people who, from the rise of the [Soviet Union's] space programme in the 1950s, through to the third world revolutions of the 1960s and 1970s in Vietnam, Iran and elsewhere, and to the emergence of Japan, Europe and now China as major economic powers, have predicted that US dominance, predominance, hegemony or, in more recent, [[post–Cold War era|post–Cold War]] terms, "unipolarity", are ebbing away.{{sfnp|Halliday|2008|p=12}}}} The predictions of these individuals represent the fluidity of power over time, through the idea that, during the period where the US was unequivocally dominant, people could still see the inevitable future, of a change in power and authority, on the world stage. ==Criticism== Among the criticisms of the theory of posthegemony is Richard Johnson's, that it involves "a marked reduction of social complexity."{{sfnp|Johnson|2007|p=102}} Johnson concedes that "one considerable achievement of 'the post-hegemony project' is to draw many observable [[post-9/11]] features into a single imaginative picture, while also synthesizing different currents in contemporary social theory." But he argues that "it is strange, however, that the result is viewed as the end of hegemony rather than as a new hegemonic moment."{{sfnp|Johnson|2007|p=102}} He, therefore, calls for a rejuvenation of the concept of hegemony, rather than its abandonment. ==See also== * [[Postnationalism]] * [[James C. Scott]] == Notes == {{reflist|22em}} ==Bibliography== {{refbegin|35em|indent=yes}} : {{cite journal |last=Beasley-Murray |first=Jon |year=2003 |title=On Posthegemony |journal=Bulletin of Latin American Research |volume=22 |issue=1 |pages=117–125 |doi=10.1111/1470-9856.00067 |ref=harv }} : {{cite book |last=Beasley-Murray |first=Jon |author-mask={{long dash}} |year=2010 |title=Posthegemony: Political Theory and Latin America |location=Minneapolis, Minnesota |publisher=University of Minnesota Press |isbn=978-0-8166-4714-9 |ref=harv }} : {{cite book |last=Hagopian |first=Patrick |year=2009 |title=The Vietnam War in American Memory: Veterans, Memorials, and the Politics of Healing |location=Amherst, Massachusetts |publisher=University of Massachusetts Press |isbn=978-1-55849-693-4 |ref=harv }} : {{cite speech |last=Halliday |first=Fred |author-link=Fred Halliday |year=2008 |title=International Relations in a Post-Hegemonic Age |url=http://www.lse.ac.uk/assets/richmedia/channels/publicLecturesAndEvents/transcripts/20080130_FredHalliday_tr.pdf |event=Valedictory Lecture as Montague Burton Professor of International Relations |location=London |publisher=London School of Economics and Political Science |access-date=10 June 2018 |ref=harv }} : {{cite book |last1=Hardt |first1=Michael |author1-link=Michael Hardt |last2=Negri |title=Multitude: War and Democracy in the Age of Empire |location=London |publisher=Hamish Hamilton |isbn=978-0-241-14240-0 |ref=harv |title-link=Multitude: War and Democracy in the Age of Empire }} I Don't Think So |journal=Theory, Culture, and Society |volume=24 |issue=3 |pages=95–110 |doi=10.1177/0263276407075958 |issn=1460-3616 |ref=harv }} : {{cite book |last=Moreiras |first=Alberto |author-link=Alberto Moreiras |year=2001 |title=The Exhaustion of Difference: The Politics of Latin American Cultural Studies |location=Durham, North Carolina |publisher=Duke University Press |isbn=978-0-8223-2726-4 |ref=harv }} : {{cite journal |last=Thoburn |first=Nicholas |year=2007 |title=Patterns of Production: Cultural Studies after Hegemony |journal=Theory, Culture, and Society |volume=24 |issue=3 |pages=79–94 |doi=10.1177/0263276407075959 |issn=1460-3616 |ref=harv }} : {{Cite book |last=Williams |first=Gareth |year=2002 |title=The Other Side of the Popular Neoliberalism and Subalternity in Latin America |location=Durham, North Carolina |publisher=Duke University Press |isbn=978-0-8223-2925-1 |ref=harv }} : {{cite journal |last=Yúdice |first=George |year=1995 |title=Civil Society, Consumption, and Governmentality in an Age of Global Restructuring: An Introduction |journal=Social Text |issue=45 |pages=1–25 |jstor=466672 |issn=0164-2472 |ref=harv }} {{refend}} ==Further reading== {{refbegin|35em|indent=yes}} : {{cite journal |last=Lash |first=Scott |author-link=Scott Lash |year=2007 |title=Power after Hegemony: Cultural Studies in Mutation? |journal=Theory, Culture, and Society |volume=24 |issue=3 |pages=55–78 |doi=10.1177/0263276407075956 |issn=1460-3616 |ref=harv }} {{refend}} ==External links== * [http://www.posthegemony.org Posthegemony], a blog on "Hegemony, Posthegemony, and Related Matters" {{Portal bar|Culture|International relations|Political science|Social and political philosophy}} {{Use British English Oxford spelling|date=June 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} [[Category:Political philosophy]] [[Category:Philosophical concepts]] [[Category:Critical theory]] [[Category:Cultural studies]] [[Category:Marxist theory]] [[Category:Hegemony]] [[Category:Cultural hegemony]] [[Category:Continental philosophy]] [[Category:Marxism]] [[Category:Social theories]] [[Category:Postmodernism]]

'''RedditGifts''' is an online user-to-user [[gift exchange]] service that connects [[Reddit]] users around the world with one another. Free to participate in, RedditGifts was first created by Reddit user "kickme444" (the alias of Dan McComas), while working on freelance projects. The service involves signing up, filling out a profile based on the user's preferences, and agreeing to send a gift to a randomly assigned user.<ref name="IrishTimesRG">{{cite news|last1=Boran|first1=Marie|title=Give and receive gifts online with Redditgifts|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/business/technology/give-and-receive-gifts-online-with-redditgifts-1.2789833|accessdate=April 9, 2018|work=The Irish Times|date=September 15, 2016}}</ref>
==Overview== The service is a [[gift exchange]] designed for Reddit users. It matches a Reddit user with another Reddit user, and each user must then send a gift to the other user according to that user's tastes and preferences listed on their profile.<ref name="TechCrunchRG">{{cite news|last1=Kumparak|first1=Greg|title=Reddit Acquires Fan-Made Secret Santa Site, RedditGifts|url=https://techcrunch.com/2011/08/23/reddit-acquires-redditgifts/|accessdate=April 9, 2018|work=TechCrunch|date=August 24, 2011}}</ref> Participation is free, although extra perks can be purchased with the optional "RedditGifts Elves" membership,<ref name="AboutRG">{{cite web|title=What is this all about?|url=https://www.redditgifts.com/about/|website=RedditGifts|publisher=[[Reddit]]|accessdate=April 9, 2018}}</ref> and goods are usually priced between $10 and $25 USD.<ref name="RedditAFR">{{cite news|last1=Shih|first1=Gerry|title=Reddit aims for profitability with geek-culture bazaar|url=http://www.afr.com/business/retail/reddit-aims-for-profitability-with-geekculture-bazaar-20131228-iyd0a|accessdate=April 9, 2018|work=Australian Financial Review|date=December 29, 2013}}</ref> The service also requests that users leave "thank-you notes" for their gift-giver on the website.<ref name="GeekSundryDYK">{{cite news|last1=Fisher|first1=Jessica|title=Redditgifts: Why I Send Presents to Strangers|url=https://geekandsundry.com/redditgifts-why-i-send-presents-to-strangers/|accessdate=April 9, 2018|work=Geek & Sundry|date=September 13, 2015}}</ref>
Since starting as a [[Secret Santa]] exchange, RedditGifts has added a variety of different themed exchanges that run throughout the year, such as [[Nintendo]] and [[Halloween]].<ref name="AboutRG" /> The service also runs Arbitrary Day, "a celebration of nothing in particular". Up to 2011, approximately $1.5 million had been spent by Reddit users on the project.{{cn|date=May 2018}}
Microsoft chairman and philanthropist [[Bill Gates]] has participated in the service for five years under the username "thisisbillgates",<ref name="BillGatesFiveTimes">{{cite news|last1=Clifford|first1=Catherine|title=Billionaire Bill Gates was this cat lover’s Secret Santa — here’s the epic haul of gifts he gave her|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/12/22/what-billionaire-bill-gates-gave-his-reddit-secret-santa.html|accessdate=April 9, 2018|work=CNBC|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|date=December 22, 2017}}</ref> most notably in 2013 and in 2014,<ref name="BusinessInsiderRG">{{cite news|last1=D'Onfro|first1=Jillian|title=Bill Gates Got One Lucky Reddit User An Incredibly Thoughtful Secret Santa Gift|url=https://www.businessinsider.com.au/bill-gates-reddit-secret-santa-gift-2014-12|accessdate=April 9, 2018|work=Business Insider Australia|date=December 22, 2014}}</ref> The [[Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation]] confirmed this.<ref name="BillGatesSMH">{{cite news|last1=Prakash|first1=Neha|title=Bill Gates gives secret Santa present on Reddit|url=https://www.smh.com.au/technology/bill-gates-gives-secret-santa-present-on-reddit-20131220-2zozf.html|accessdate=April 9, 2018|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|publisher=Fairfax|date=December 20, 2013}}</ref> Gates was noted to send objects to Reddit users like "Calid7" (a 25-year-old Californian woman),<ref name="BusinessInsiderRG" /> such as a travel book and a stuffed cow.<ref name="RedditAFR" /> He has also been known to donate to charities in the name of the user he has been matched with.<ref name="BusinessInsiderRG" />
==History== RedditGifts was originally created by Reddit user Dan McComas,<ref name="DailyBeastRG">{{cite news|last1=Ries|first1=Brian|title=Secret Santa: The Creator of Reddit's Gift Exchange, the World's Biggest|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/secret-santa-the-creator-of-reddits-gift-exchange-the-worlds-biggest|accessdate=April 9, 2018|work=The Daily Beast|date=December 19, 2010}}</ref> or "kickme444" as known on the site, and "5days". McComas first conceived the idea while working on freelance projects in 2009.<ref name="DailyBeastRG" />
The site was launched in 2009 with 4,500 participants;<ref name="TechCrunchRG" /> the website reports that 212,894 people worldwide participated in the event during 2014.<ref name="BusinessInsiderRG" />
The site is a three-time [[Guinness World Record]] holder for the World's Largest Gift Exchange.<ref name="WorldRecordRG">{{cite web|title=redditgifts Secret Santa Guinness World Record|url=https://www.redditgifts.com/blog/view/worldrecord/|website=RedditGifts|publisher=[[Reddit]]|accessdate=April 9, 2018}}</ref><ref name="WorldRecordGWR">{{cite web|title=Largest online Secret Santa game|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/largest-online-secret-santa-game|website=Guinness World Records|accessdate=April 9, 2018}}</ref>
===Reddit acquisition=== In August 2011, Reddit bought the RedditGifts site. The two site-runners reportedly could not afford to continue maintaining the site while simultaneously working their day jobs. Both site-runners continued to run the website, although they are not involved with the daily operations of Reddit.<ref name="TechCrunchRG" /> The company takes a 15 to 20 percent cut of every purchase. Reddit operates the website as part of its ongoing plans to monetise their website. As of December 2013, approximately 14 percent of Reddit's revenue came from running the service, although McComas said that those sales alone could "put Reddit firmly in the black", and that the company may choose to reinvest funds in [[e-commerce]] customer service and infrastructure.<ref name="RedditAFR" />
In December 2013, while expressing his desire for the Reddit business to become self-sustaining, then-Chief Executive [[Yishan Wong]] stated that the RedditGifts service "provides real value", and called it "promising" for the business. Wong increased the staff count dedicated to the project to eight after realising the service's potential.<ref name="RedditAFR" />

{{Italic title}} '''{{lang|la|Reductio ad Hitlerum}}''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|h|ɪ|t|l|ər|əm}}; pseudo-Latin for "reduction to Hitler"; sometimes '''''argumentum ad Hitlerum''''', "argument to Hitler", '''{{lang|la|ad Nazium}}''', "to Nazism"), or '''playing the Nazi card''', is an attempt to invalidate someone else's position on the basis that the same view was held by [[Adolf Hitler]] or the [[Nazi Party]], for example: "Hitler was against tobacco smoking, X is against tobacco smoking, therefore X is a Nazi". Coined by [[Leo Strauss]] in 1953, {{lang|la|reductio ad Hitlerum}} borrows its name from the term used in logic, {{lang|la|[[reductio ad absurdum]]}} (reduction to the absurd).Leo Strauss, ''Natural Right and History''. Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1965 [1953], p. 42. According to Strauss, {{lang|la|reductio ad Hitlerum}} is a form of {{lang|la|[[ad hominem]]}}, {{lang|la|[[argumentum ad misericordiam|ad misericordiam]]}}, or a {{lang|la|[[Ignoratio elenchi|fallacy of irrelevance]]}}. The suggested rationale is one of [[association fallacy|guilt by association]]. It is a tactic often used to derail arguments, because such comparisons tend to distract and anger the opponent, as Hitler and Nazism have been condemned in the modern world.{{cite web|url=http://www.fallacyfiles.org/adnazium.html|title=Logical Fallacy: The Hitler Card|work=Fallacy Files|year=2004|last=Curtis|first=Gary N.|accessdate=2007-10-08}} ==Fallacious nature== {{lang|la|Reductio ad Hitlerum}} is a form of [[association fallacy]].{{cite web|url=http://www.fallacyfiles.org/guiltbya.html|title=Logical Fallacy: Guilt by Association|work=Fallacy Files|year=2004|last=Curtis|first=Gary N.|accessdate=2007-10-08}} The argument is that a policy leads to {{ndash}} or is the same as {{ndash}} one advocated or implemented by [[Adolf Hitler]] or the [[Third Reich]] and so "proves" that the original policy is undesirable. Another instance of {{lang|la|reductio ad Hitlerum}} is asking a question of the form "You know who else...?" with the deliberate intent of impugning a certain idea or action by implying Hitler held that idea or performed such action.{{cite web| url=http://ask.metafilter.com/71925/You-know-who-else-Origin |title=You know who else ___? Origin? - catchphrase meme |publisher=Ask MetaFilter |date= |accessdate=2013-01-10}} An invocation of Hitler or Nazism is not a {{lang|la|reductio ad Hitlerum}} when it illuminates the argument instead of causing distraction from it.{{aut|Gabriel H. Teninbaum}}, [http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=1445423 ''Reduction ad Hitlerum'': Trumping the Judicial Nazi Card]. Michigan State Law Review, Vol. 2009, p. 541-578, 2009 ==History== The phrase {{lang|la|reductio ad Hitlerum}} is first known to have been used in an article written by [[University of Chicago]] professor [[Leo Strauss]] for ''Measure: A Critical Journal'' in spring 1951;{{cite book|last=Hutchins|first=Robert Maynard|title=Measure: A Critical Journal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6z3WAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=5 February 2014|year=1951|publisher=H. Regnery Company}} it was made famous in a book by the same author published in 1953{{cite web|url=http://www.ou.edu/cas/psc/bookstrauss.htm |title=Natural Right and History|work=University of Oklahoma|year=2008|accessdate=2008-08-11}} ''Natural Right and History'', Chapter II:
In following this movement towards its end we shall inevitably reach a point beyond which the scene is darkened by the shadow of Hitler. Unfortunately, it does not go without saying that in our examination we must avoid the fallacy that in the last decades has frequently been used as a substitute for the {{lang|la|reductio ad absurdum}}: the {{lang|la|reductio ad Hitlerum}}. A view is not refuted by the fact that it happens to have been shared by Hitler.
The phrase was derived from the legitimate [[logical argument]] called {{lang|la|reductio ad absurdum}}. The {{lang|la|argumentum}} variant takes its form from the names of many classic fallacies, such as {{lang|la|argumentum ad hominem}}. The {{lang|la|ad Nazium}} variant may be further derived, humorously, from {{lang|la|[[Ad nauseam|argumentum ad nauseam]]}}. In 2000, [[Thomas Fleming (political writer)|Thomas Fleming]] described its use against traditional values:
Leo Strauss called it the {{lang|la|reductio ad Hitlerum}}. If Hitler liked neoclassical art, that means that classicism in every form is Nazi; if Hitler wanted to strengthen the German family, that makes the traditional family (and its defenders) Nazi; if Hitler spoke of the "nation" or the "folk", then any invocation of nationality, ethnicity, or even folkishness is Nazi ...Thomas Fleming, editor, ''Chronicles'' (Rockford, Illinois), May 2000, p. 11.
==Limits to classification as a fallacy== Some historians studying [[the Holocaust]] argue that not all comparisons to Hitler and Nazism are logical fallacies since if they all were, there would be nothing to learn from the events that led to the Holocaust. That would undermine the entire significance of studying the Holocaust to avoid future [[genocide]]s.[https://search.proquest.com/openview/8690dfba45e051dab6cbf8b92ef45f3b/1?pq-origsite=gscholar&cbl=589 Hitler's Willing Executioners: Ordinary Germans and the Holocaust], Daniel Jonah Goldhagen 1997"Eichmann was Outrageously Stupid". Hannah Arendt: The Last Interview: And Other Conversations. November 9, 1964. Proponents of this point do make distinctions between many different categories of comparison(s) to Hitler, some of which are fallacies, some of which are not, and some of which may or may not be fallacies. This approach is also critical to strict refusal to acknowledge similarities to the Holocaust, since there were early stages leading up to it and policies today can be comparable to those without being comparable to the "final solution". Advocates of this approach argue that such early stages are those where something can really be done about it, before it is too late.Y. Michael Barilan, 2004 Categories include: * Similarities that are not in any way related to political or institutional decision making, e.g. going on walks or wearing expensive clothes. These are invariably fallacies when used as arguments. * Similarities that are related to politics, in the absence of centralized power. This example usually refers to political party and movements still struggling to gain power. These similarities can only be to early stages of Nazism, not to a full-blown organized genocide. These comparisons may or may not be fallacies: a detailed analysis of methods, decision-making and ideology is necessary to determine that. * Pointing out that Hitler did some things that are often considered to be related to being good in the context of criticizing psychological assumptions of them being connected, without implying that anyone doing them are like Hitler in other ways. E.g. that Hitler's engagement for animal protection shows that treatment of animals is divorced from treatment of humans, not implying a negative connection but mere non-connection. This is not an example of the fallacy, though not directly related to the study of organized genocide either. * Pointing out that the Nazis believed in some things that are often thought to be protection from persecution within the context of rejecting assumptions about connections between concepts and tolerance. For example, that the Nazis believed [[homosexuality]] to be innate and, far from tolerating it, extended their [[homophobia]] to relatives as well, just to show that ideas on origin of a behavior (in this case homosexuality, but also applicable to other things) is unrelated to tolerance of said behavior and not implying that an idea is Nazi-like. This is not a fallacy. It does not show what should be done to prevent repetition, but it narrows it down by eliminating irrelevancies. * Pointing out similarities between the Nazi [[command hierarchy|chain of command]] and modern chain of command as a risk factor for genocide shared between Nazi and modern society in general without applying it to individuals specifically, e.g. that administrative and military laws are significant risk factors. It does not imply advocacy of a repetition of the [[Nuremberg trials]] to those who only follow orders/obey laws, partly since referring to that trial as a source of authority would promote the [[death penalty]] exactly as much as "superior orders is no defense" and partly since forcing individual executioners into a damned if you do and damned if you don't situation is ineffective for preventing organized genocides like the Holocaust. Instead, it is criticism of structures and laws that lead to dangerous officiousness. This is not a fallacy. It is relevant for genocide studies. ===Antecedents=== Although named for and formalized around Hitler, the logical fallacy existed prior to the [[Second World War]]. There were other individuals from history who were used as stand-ins for pure evil.{{cite web |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/briefing/explainer/2011/10/hank_williams_jr_firing_who_was_the_rhetorical_worst_person_in_h.html |title=Before Hitler, Who Was the Stand-In for Pure Evil? |work=Slate |author=Brian Palmer |date=October 4, 2011 |accessdate=November 27, 2014}} In the 18th, 19th and early 20th centuries the [[Pharaoh of the Exodus|Pharaoh of the Book of Exodus]] was commonly seen as the most villainous person in history. In the years prior to the Civil War, abolitionists referred to slaveholders as modern-day Pharaohs. After [[VE Day]], Pharaoh continued to appear in the speeches of social reformers like [[Martin Luther King Jr.]] [[Judas Iscariot]] and [[Pontius Pilate]] were also commonly held up as pure evil. However, there was no universal Hitler-like person and different regions and times used different stand-ins. In the years after the [[American Revolution]], [[King George III]] was often vilified in the United States. [[Andrew Jackson]] was also called [[King Andrew the First]]. During the Civil War, some Southerners spoke of Lincoln in Hitler-like terms. Some Confederates even called Lincoln a "modern Pharaoh". ==Invocations== In 1991, Michael André Bernstein alleged {{lang|la|reductio ad Hitlerum}} over a full-page advertisement placed in ''[[The New York Times]]'' by the [[Lubavitch]] community, following the [[Crown Heights Riot]], under the heading "This Year ''[[Kristallnacht]]'' Took Place on August 19th Right Here in Crown Heights." [[Henry Schwarzschild]], who had witnessed ''Kristallnacht'', wrote to the ''New York Times'' that "however ugly were the anti-Semitic slogans and the assaultive behavior of people in the streets [during the Crown Heights riots]... one thing that clearly did not take place was a ''Kristallnacht''."{{cite web|quote=The Lubavitcher community itself, in the form of the 'Crown Heights Emergency Fund,' placed a full-page advertisement in ''The New York Times'' on September 20, 1991, under the heading 'This Year Kristallnacht Took Place on August 19th Right Here in Crown Heights.' Their version of Leo Strauss's {{lang|la|reductio ad Hitlerum}} was rightly perceived by those who had been in Germany on Kristallnacht (November 9, 1938) as an outrageous comparison.|url=http://www.escholarship.org/editions/view?docId=ft3x0nb2ns|title=Foregone Conclusions|publisher=Escholarship.org|accessdate=2011-07-07}} American conservative radio and television host [[Glenn Beck]] is often criticized for his frequent use of {{lang|la|reductio ad Hitlerum}}, including a controversial statement comparing the victims of the [[2011 Norway attacks]] to members of the [[Hitler Youth]].{{cite news|url=http://newsfeed.time.com/2011/07/26/glenn-beck-site-of-norway-massacre-sounds-like-the-hitler-youth/|title=Glenn Beck: Site of Norway Massacre 'Sounds like the Hitler Youth'|work=Time|date=2011-07-26}} Beck has also compared the [[National Endowment for the Arts]] to [[Joseph Goebbels]]''The Glenn Beck Show'', November 3, 2009. and [[Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now|ACORN]] to Hitler's [[Sturmabteilung|"Brown Shirts"]].''The Glenn Beck Show'', May 7, 2009. ''[[The American Conservative]]'' accused [[Jonah Goldberg]]'s book ''[[Liberal Fascism]]'' of employing the {{lang|la|reductio}} fallacy:
That Nazism and contemporary liberalism both promote healthy living is as meaningless a finding as that [[Bloody Mary (cocktail)|bloody marys]] and [[martini (cocktail)|martinis]] may both be made with [[gin]]. Repeatedly, Goldberg fails to recognize a {{lang|la|reductio ad absurdum}}. ... In no case does Goldberg uncover anything more ominous than a coincidence.{{cite web|url=http://www.theamericanconservative.com/articles/goldbergs-trivial-pursuit/|title=Goldberg's Trivial Pursuit|author=Austin Bramwell|date=January 28, 2008|work=The American Conservative|accessdate=30 January 2014}}
==See also== * [[Godwin's law]] * [[List of fallacies]] * ''[[Reductio ad Stalinum]]'' ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/10618638|title=Is it ever OK to call someone a Nazi?|publisher=BBC News|date=14 July 2010}} * [http://www.spiegel.de/fotostrecke/fotostrecke-60763.html Toying with Hitler and History] – slideshow by ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' * [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/lincoln-mitchell/mike-huckabees-ireducto-a_b_3033369.html Mike Huckabee's reductio ad Hitlerum, Lincoln Mitchell, April 7 2013] * {{cite journal|last1=Harris|first1=Adam J. L.|last2=Hsu|first2=Anne S.|last3=Madsen|first3=Jens K.|title=Because Hitler did it! Quantitative tests of Bayesian argumentation using ad hominem|url=http://www.ucl.ac.uk/lagnado-lab/publications/harris/Harris_Hsu_Madsen_2012.pdf|journal=Thinking & Reasoning|volume=18|issue=3|pages=311–343|publisher=Psychology Press|accessdate=14 January 2015|location=London, UK|format=PDF|doi=10.1080/13546783.2012.670753|date=11 June 2012}} {{Relevance fallacies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Reductio ad Hitlerum}} [[Category:Genetic fallacies]] [[Category:Informal fallacies]] [[Category:Relevance fallacies]] [[Category:Dog Latin words and phrases]] [[Category:Thought experiments in ethics]]

The '''Roy model''' is one of the earliest works in economics on [[Self-selection (labor economics)|self-selection]] due to [[A.D. Roy]]. The basic model considers two types of workers that choose occupation in one of two sectors.
==Original model== Roy's original paper deals with workers selecting into fishing and hunting professions, where there is no uncertainty about the amount of goods (fish or rabbits) that will be caught in a given period, but fishing is more costly as it requires more skill. The central question that Roy tries to answer in the original paper is whether the best hunters will hunt and the best fishermen will fish. While the discussion is non-mathematical, it is observed that choices will depend on the distribution of skills, the correlation between these skills in the population, and the technology available to use these skills.<ref>Roy, A. (1951): Some Thoughts on the Distribution of Earnings. Oxford Economic Papers 3(2), pp. 135-146.</ref>
==Further developments== [[George Borjas]] was the first to formalize the model of Roy in a mathematical sense and apply it to self-selection in [[immigration]]. Specifically, assume source country 0 and destination country 1, with log earnings in a country ''i'' given by ''w<sub>i</sub>= a<sub>i</sub> + e<sub>i</sub>'', where ''e<sub>i</sub>∼N(0, <math>s_i^2</math> )''. Additionally, assume there is a cost ''C'' associated with migrating from country 0 to country 1 and workers know all parameters and their own realization of e<sub>0</sub> and e<sub>1</sub>. Borjas then uses the implications of the Roy model to infer something about what wages for immigrants in country 1 would have been had they stayed in country 0 and what wages for non-immigrants in country 0 would have been had they migrated. The third, and final, element needed for this is the correlation between the wages in the two countries, ''ρ''. A worker will choose to immigrate if ''a<sub>1</sub> - a<sub>0</sub> - C + e<sub>1</sub> - e<sub>0</sub> > 0'' which will happen with probability ''1 - Φ ( v )'' where ''v'' is <math> \frac {(a_{1} - a_{0}-{C})}{s_{v}} </math> , ''s<sub>v</sub>'' is the standard deviation of ''e<sub>1</sub> – e<sub>0</sub>'', and ''Φ'' is the standard normal cdf.<ref> Borjas, G. J. (1987): Self-Selection and the Earnings of Immigrants. American Economic Review 77(4), pp. 531-553.</ref> This leads to the famous central result that the expected wage for immigrants depends on the selection mechanism, as shown in equation (1), where ''ϕ'' is the standard normal pdf and, like before, ''Φ'' is the standard normal cdf.
''E[w<sub>0</sub>'' |''Immigrate''] = a<sub>0</sub> +ρs<sub>0</sub> <math> (\frac {\phi ({v})}{1-\phi ({v}) }) </math> (1)
While Borjas was the first to mathematically formalize the Roy model, it has guided thinking in other fields of research as well. A famous example by [[James Heckman]] and [[Bo Honoré]] who study [[labor market participation]] using the Roy model, where the choice equation leads to the [[Heckman correction]] procedure.<ref> Heckman, J. J., Honoré, B. E. (1990): The Empirical Content of the Roy Model. Econometrica 58(5), pp. 1121-1149.</ref> More generally, Heckman and Vytlacil propose the Roy model as an alternative to the LATE framework proposed by Angrist and Imbens.<ref> Heckman, J. J., Vytlacil, E. (2007): Econometric evaluation of social programs, part I: Causal models, structural models and econometric policy evaluation. Handbook of Econometrics, Vol. 6, ed. by J. J. Heckman, and E. E. Leamer. North Holland.</ref><ref> Imbens, G. W., Angrist, J. D. (1994): Identification and Estimation of Local Average Treatment Effects. Econometrica 62(2), pp. 467-475.</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{globalize|article|Europe and the English-speaking world|date=February 2016}} __NOTOC__ [[File:Briefoeffner mit kuvert und hand fcm.jpg|thumb|Someone opening a letter before it has been delivered commits a crime]] The '''secrecy of correspondence''' ({{lang-de|Briefgeheimnis}}, {{lang-fr|secret de la correspondance}}) or literally translated as '''secrecy of letters''', is a fundamental [[legal principle]] enshrined in the [[constitution]]s of several European countries.{{Cite journal |title=The Legal Protection of the Secrecy of Correspondence |author=Roxana Maria |journal=Curentul ”Juridic” |year=2009 |number=1 |location=Tîrgu-Mureş, România |url=http://revcurentjur.ro/arhiva/attachments_200901/recjurid091_10F.pdf }}{{Cite book |title=1936 Constitution of the USSR |chapter=Chapter X, Fundamental Rights and Duties of Citizens, Article 128 |url=http://www.departments.bucknell.edu/russian/const/36cons04.html#chap10 |quote=The inviolability of the homes of citizens and privacy of correspondence are protected by law.}} {{Cite book |title=Constitutional Law in Greece |author1=Philippos K. Spyropoulos |author2=Philippos C. Spyropoulos |author3=Theodore P. Fortsakis |page=228 |publisher=Kluwer Law International |year=2009 |isbn=9789041128782 |url=https://books.google.fi/books?id=fJS-Ly83TpMC&lpg=PA228&dq=Secrecy%20of%20letters%20and%20all%20other%20forms%20of%20free%20correspondence%20or%20%20communication%20shall%20be%20absolutely%20inviolable&pg=PA228#v=onepage&q&f=false }}{{Cite web |title=Right to Privacy of Correspondence of Other Countries (section: Greece) |date=June 15, 2013 |author=DAVID JOHN MAROTTA |url=http://www.marottaonmoney.com/right-to-privacy-of-correspondence-of-other-countries/ }} It guarantees that the content of sealed [[Letter (message)|letters]] is never revealed and letters in transit are not opened by [[government]] officials or any other third party. It is thus the main legal basis for the assumption of '''privacy of correspondence'''.{{Citation needed|date=February 2012}} The principle has been naturally extended to other forms of [[telecommunication|communication]], including [[telephony]] and [[electronic communication]]s on the [[Internet]] as the constitutional guarantees are generally thought to cover also these forms of communication.{{Cite web |title=Constitution to extend protection to e-mails |date=11 July 2014 |publisher=Ministry of the Interior and Kingdom Relations - Government of the Netherlands |url=http://www.government.nl/ministries/bzk/news/2014/07/16/constitution-to-extend-protection-to-e-mails.html }} However, national telecommunications privacy laws may allow [[lawful interception]], i.e. [[wiretapping]] and monitoring of electronic communications in cases of [[Suspect|suspicion of crime]]. Paper letters have in most jurisdictions remained outside the legal scope of law enforcement [[surveillance]], even in cases of ''"reasonable searches and seizures"''. When applied to electronic communication, the principle protects not only the content of the communication, but also the information on when and to whom any messages (if any) have been sent (see: [[Call detail record]]s), and in the case of [[Mobile phone|mobile communication]], the [[location information]] of the mobile units. As a consequence, in jurisdictions with a safeguard on secrecy of letters, location data collected from mobile phone networks has a higher level of protection than data collected by [[vehicle telematics]] or transport tickets. ==United States== {{See also|Third-party doctrine}} In the [[United States]] there is no specific constitutional guarantee on the privacy of correspondence. The secrecy of letters and correspondence is derived through [[litigation]] from the [[Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution]]. In an 1877 case the [[U.S. Supreme Court]] stated:
No law of [[United States Congress|Congress]] can place in the hands of officials connected with the [[United States Postal Service|Postal Service]] any authority to invade the '''secrecy of letters''' and such sealed packages in the mail; and all regulations adopted as to mail matter of this kind must be in subordination to the great principle embodied in the fourth amendment of the [[United States Constitution|Constitution]].''Ex parte Jackson'', {{ussc| source=f |96|727|1877| pin=733}}
The protection of the Fourth Amendment has been extended beyond the home in other instances. A protection similar to that of correspondence has [[California v. Greenwood|even been argued]] to extend to the contents of [[trash can]]s outside one's house, although unsuccessfully. Like all rights derived through litigation, the secrecy of correspondence is subject to interpretations. By Supreme Court precedent, rights derived from the Fourth Amendment are limited by the legal test of a "[[reasonable expectation of privacy]]". ==See also== * [[Black room]] * [[Data privacy]] * [[Dead letter]] * [[Electronic Communications Privacy Act]] * ''[[Katz v. United States]]'' * [[Lawful interception]] * [[Postal censorship]] * [[Telecommunications data retention]] == References == * [http://www.ficora.fi/englanti/tietoturva/svt.htm Act on the Protection of Privacy] at the Finnish Communications Regulatory Authority site * [https://www.aclu.org/privacy/gen/15444leg20001018.html Letter to the House On the Privacy of Outbound U.S. Mail (10/18/2000)] by [[ACLU]] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110722034442/http://legalworkshop.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/04/stan-a-0005-desai.pdf Anuj C. Desai. The Post Office and the Birth of Communications Privacy] {{Reflist|2}} == External links == * [https://www.nytimes.com/2006/01/13/opinion/13kahn.html Back when spies played by the rules] by [[David Kahn (writer)|David Kahn]], [[New York Times]] - A history of the secrecy of letters {{Authority control}} [[Category:Privacy of telecommunications]] [[Category:Privacy]] [[Category:Postal system]] [[Category:Freedom of expression]] [[pl:Tajemnica pocztowa]]
